content: After using Conversations for more than two years gladly (apart from a few minor UX mistakes and questionable decisions) it now undergoes harsh changes with version 2.0.  OMEMO is now enabled by default for _all_ new chats. This, while beeing a good way onboarding, has to be turned off inconviniently for every single chat manually if the user does not want it to be shoved down the throat for whatever reason. This may have easily been an option in "expert settings". Further, OTR support was removed without any public comment, explanation and perceptible rationale. While manual resource naming (as sensible common practice since the inception of Jabber) has _never_ been there, Conversations at least gave the user the ability to choose from a set of predefined and distinguishable resource presets. This, while not ideal, was sufficient. Now, this option has also been cut down without any rationale.  These, amongst other changes in earlier versions, e.g. the perky "conversations.im" commercial nagging when adding your Jabber account, reveals the dark path that lies ahead to the walled garden of other mobile messenger failures.  One star until sanity is restored.
replyContent: Have a look at Conversations Legacy https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=eu.siacs.conversations.legacy

content: I really like business model of this application, It's free software but to download it from google play you have to pay. There are lot of implication in favour of user.   Problem with IM+ or other xmpp + OTR app was that I never wasn't sure if OTR is done on my cellphone or on their servers. I didn't know if keys are stored also in their servers or only in my device. But with this application because of free software nature you have source codes so you are able to audit code if you want.   Also in previous I had problem with IM+ Pro and their support doesn't act at all. But with free software app I don't need to relay on official support and I can just support it by myself or buy support from third party. There is no proprietary lock up.   I'm also supprised how well this app does work. I tried to turn off app and then ping my xmpp client, and I get that message immediatelly. content: Full Disclosure: The developer of this app is a friend of mine.  I've been beta-testing this app for a while, and it is the first XMPP client that I've actually found myself using quite a bit. It's built with a clean design and is packed with obscure-but-useful features.  I especially appreciate the nice balance of customizability and simplicity, where other clients tend to err on the side of too many options. This results in a really streamlined, well thought-out user experience. One can tell that a great deal of attention is payed to UX design. Another thing that makes this client really stick out is the support for various XEPs, which really, noticably improve mobility performance.   Keep in mind that this is a somewhat early version of the app, so occasionally, I still run into bugs, but these are usually fixed very quickly by the developer.
